title: Kinetic energy of an ascending leaking bucket

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students set up the Atwood machine shown in the figure above, which consists of a light string passing over a pulley whose mass and friction are negligible. A counterweight of constant mass is connected to the right end of the string. A bucket full of water is connected to the left end of the string. The counterweight has a mass less than that of the full bucket, but greater than that of the empty bucket. At time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> the system is released from rest with the bucket full. At the same time, water begins to flow out of the bucket through a hole on the side near the bottom. The graph above shows the velocity of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals 6 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where positive velocity represents upward velocity for the counterweight. The bucket and counterweight continue moving long after this time. (a) At what time is the mass of the bucket and water equal to the mass of the counterweight? Explain your reasoning.

A group of students set up the Atwood machine shown in the figure above, which consists of a light string passing over a pulley whose mass and friction are negligible. A counterweight of constant mass is connected to the right end of the string. A bucket full of water is connected to the left end of the string. The counterweight has a mass less than that of the full bucket, but greater than that of the empty bucket. At time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> the system is released from rest with the bucket full. At the same time, water begins to flow out of the bucket through a hole on the side near the bottom. The graph above shows the velocity of the counterweight above its initial position as a function of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals 6 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, where positive velocity represents upward velocity for the counterweight. The bucket and counterweight continue moving long after this time. (a) At what time is the mass of the bucket and water equal to the mass of the counterweight? Explain your reasoning.
(b) At what time is the mechanical energy of the bucket-Earth system at a minimum? Explain your reasoning.

The students model the acceleration of the counterweight using the function <math alttext="a of t, equals 1.2 minus 0.6, t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the time interval <math alttext="0 seconds is less than t, which is less than 6 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Note that positive acceleration represents upward acceleration for the counterweight.(c) Is it plausible that this function could correctly model the acceleration during this interval? Why or why not?
(d) Explain why this function does NOT correctly model the acceleration of the counterweight over a long period of time, assuming that the system is able to move for a very long time.

The students are told that the counterweight’s mass is <math alttext="5 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the mass of the bucket with water in it is approximately given by the equation <math alttext="M of t, equals 6.36 times e raised to the negative 0.12, t power, kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>6.36</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.12</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t is less than or equal to 20 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume any action-reaction forces between the bucket and the water draining are negligible.(e) Explain how the students could use this information along with the acceleration function <math alttext="a of t, equals 1.2 minus 0.6, t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to calculate the total kinetic energy of the system consisting of the bucket, the water in the bucket, the pulley, and the counterweight at time <math alttext="t equals 6 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
